bibl.title: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Philip Showalter Hench, January 5, 1947

div1.p: Cooke regrets that he is unable to help Hench identify the persons and buildings in the 1908 photographs from Pinar del Rio.

div1.head: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Philip Showalter Hench, January 5, 1947
div1.opener:
Lexington Va.
Jan. 5th 1947
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester- Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
It is with sincere regret
that I find myself unable to help you
much about the photos. taken at
Pinar del Rio in 1908.

My tour> of duty there was so
long ago and I remained there
such a short time (I think
about 3 weeks) beginning about
June 30th 1900. That my recollections
are very dim.

I don't think I left
the post area but a few times
and was in the town very
seldom; It had few attractions
and I dont seem to remem-
ber the buildings in your
photos. At a guess I would
say that photo no. 3 shows
post buildings, including new
barracks occupied by American troops
in 1900, and the building in the
background near the water tank
was probably "the post hospital."

I'm sure I was never in
the cuartel or guard house. The
latter was probably in the
Cuartel.- The hospital was
not. It was a separate
building in the post area,
I am certain the tent hospital
was established after I left,
probably late in August or
Early September 1900 after the
nature of the epidemic was
determined and after I was
transferred- I was never in this camp I believe the
whole garrison was sent to
this Camp (Pre Aedes Egypti.!)

Other Medical Officers on
the post with me were Capt Godfrey,
post surg. Dr Pinto and a Danish
American physician, said to
be a Yellow Fever specialist. Whose
name I can't recall. Pinto was
ordered to the Philippines and
may still be living. The invest-
igations were made as I recall,
after I left the post.

I had never seen a case of
Yellow Fever before my Cuban service
and had very little contact
with these patients during
my stay at P. del R.

I do recall that microscopic
blood examinations were being
made everyday and I was
told that the finding's definitely
indicated the pernicious type
of malaria and that Dr ______
the Yellow Fever specialist
concurred in this diagnosis.

p.add:
Thank you for letting
me see the photos.

div1.p:
I was not trained in labora-
tory technique and had no
part in this work.

We appreciated your Christmas card
and it has been a real pleasure
to hear from you again we hope
you will look in on us when you
are next in Virginia- I am now re-
tired from Public Health and find myself
rather at loose ends! With Cordial Regards
from us all
